Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: The nun has been chosen to represent the convent and lead a prayer vigil at a major public religious event.
Story:
I sat on the edge of my narrow bed, phone in hand, the screen still lit up with my boyfriend’s last message. We’d argued again—this time about money, about how I never seemed to have enough time for him, about how I was always distracted. He wanted me to come over, to talk things through, to finally resolve the tension that had been building all week. I knew he expected me to be present, to listen, to fight for us.

But the convent bell echoed down the hallway, a reminder that I was expected in the chapel. Tonight, of all nights, I had been chosen to lead the prayer vigil at the cathedral—a public event, a great honor, and a responsibility I could not take lightly. The sisters were counting on me to represent our community, to guide them in faith and devotion.

My heart twisted as I stared at the phone, torn between the world outside and the sacred silence within these walls. I wanted to be both: the understanding girlfriend, the devoted nun. But tonight, I could not be in two places at once.
